instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.ADAPTER_EN: What is ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that was not spilled on. It does not turn on. Main voltages are all normal. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is at 0V. CPU Vcore is at 6Ω to ground rather than the 15 or 16Ω I would normally expect. Any idea what I should make of that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: What are "main voltages"? 5V pulsing? PPVRTC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message:
No pulse on any 5V lines. PPVRTC is good at 3.3V. No shorts anywhere that I can see.

For main voltages I'm referring to the things I would normally expect to be in place for the board to switch out of an S5 state. PPBUS, 3V42, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>, voltage to the SMC. Nothing seems off which is why I was wondering if that slightly lower measurement on the resistance to ground for vcore might be an indicator of what the problem might be. Not sure where to look next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message:
So to clarify, the board is stuck in S5 state ?

Do you have a scope to measure clock signal ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: Yes, not moving beyond S5. And no clock signal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: Replace <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> to restore 32k clock.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: I replaced it. No change. <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X1</SIGNAL> has 0.6V and <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X2_R</SIGNAL> has 0V. Any thoughts on where to go next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: Check for 32kHz output on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> pin 12. Check all rails for short to GND. Check 5V rail again for pulses, they will be short and hard to catch on multimeter, better use scope.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: I was borrowing an oscilloscope but had to give it back. I have a Fluke multimeter that can measure frequency so if I can just use that I would rather not spend money on an oscilloscope. Any idea how to use a counter to measure frequency? I can't figure it out and can't find any info anywhere.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: You put the meter on freq. mode and neg probe on GND and pos. on the 32kHz output on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>. My meter says 32 then. No idea about Fluke though, compare with a known good board. Could of course be any board with an identical clock chip, so anything 2012 and up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: Thanks, I tried that on a fully functional board and must be missing something. I'm watching this guy use my exact meter and I can't get anything other than a default 60Hz [url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5EUCeY-U26U[/url] I'll have to figure out what I'm doing wrong.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message:
0.45V is a normal DC voltage at pin12 when has 32KHz output clock.
That DC voltage will not assure 100% working chip; but 0V DC points to no oscillation 100%.
Output pins 8&15 will not work before the board starts.
Check voltages at pins 5, 13 and 1.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message:
Ok, thanks, yeah, that's normally what I've been doing - just checking for voltage and comparing to a good board. I would love to figure out this frequency counter but for now I'll do it the old way.
Pin 1: 3.3V
Pin 5: 3.3V
Pin12: .45V
Pin 13: 3.4V

Also:
Pin 3: 0V
Pin 4: .5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: Lets check some basics here. <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 3.4V
<SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.4V

I noticed that <SIGNAL>PP1V05_TBT</SIGNAL> is almost shorted. It's at about 0.007 (8Ω) to ground in diode mode. I removed everything in the circuit short of <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. No change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: Not sure what the measurement is supposed to be, but keep in mind that 8Ohms on 1.05V is not a lot. (Its 138mW or 131mA)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> should be present. Is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> present?
Compare the <SIGNAL>1V05_TBT</SIGNAL> resistance to a known good board. <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> can short out more rails if it is fucked.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: On this line it's around .150 (400) to ground on a good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: No <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>. I was already thinking about pulling <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. Can I pull it and still have a chance at a functional board (w/o tbolt)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: Sure, just rip it off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: Pulled <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. Short is gone. No change though. Still no <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: You have to be worried what caused this short. Seeing that Vcore has also a lower than normal resistance I'm afraid the CPU is dead too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning on
threads.message: ok, bummer. throw it in the parts bin. thanks for the help.
